results.title: VHS
results.brief_description: The evolution of film to portable, tape-based cameras and the production and distribution of magnetic media like video continued the democratisation of the moving image. One sector that readily adopted magnetic media was education, with training and educational videos disseminated on the format. We now have a range of educational videos in our collection and the VHS camera featured here was used to shoot classes on filmmaking when ACMI was part of Cinemedia in the late 1990s. Rapid deterioration of video and the obsolescence of the equipment needed for playback pose critical preservation issues – we’re doing everything we can to save them.

results.title: A Long time to grow. Part III. Six, seven and eight year old society of children
results.creator_credit: L. Joseph Stone and Vassar College, Dept. of Child study
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Vassar studies: studies of normal personality development”.
Presents the social growth of the six, seven and eight year old child. They move into a bigger world, seeking the support of their own age group, through which traditional activities, games, magic and customs are handed down. At school, they learn not only the three R’s but something of human relationships. These children are marked by outgoing interest in the world around them, a powerful drive to acquire both skill and knowledge and the characteristic cleavage of the sexes in these early school years.

results.title: This is Robert
results.creator_credit: Mary S. Fisher, L. Joseph Stone and Vassar College, Dept. of Child study
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Vassar studies: studies of normal personality development”
This film traces the development of an aggressive, “difficult” yet thoroughly appealing child from his early nursery days to his first year at a public school. Clumsy, blundering, confused by varied adult pressures, Robert’s violent and haphazard aggression is seen as a strong, defensive counter-attack on the whole world. His mother’s steadying support and his teachers’ firm consistent and affectionate treatment bring him safely through the first adolescence of the pre-school years to an outwardly smooth adjustment in public school, without his earlier inflammable outbursts.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Mary S. Fisher, L. Joseph Stone and Vassar College, Dept. of Child study

results.title: A Long time to grow. Part II. Four and five year olds in school
results.creator_credit: L. Joseph Stone and Vassar College, Dept. of Child study
results.brief_description:
Episode number 12 of Series “Vassar studies: studies of normal personality development”.
While there is considerable overlap between four and five year olds and much individual variation, in general, fours are seen in a world of activities and interests which are a perfecting and elaboration of skills and interests of two to three year olds. Fives are beginning to enter the world of older children, a more formalised enlarging world, words and numbers begin to take on some meaning.

results.title: A Long time to grow. Part I. Two and three year olds in nursery school
results.creator_credit: Mary Fisher Langmuir and Vassar College, Dept. of Child study
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Vassar studies: studies of normal personality development”
The activities of 2-3 year old children in nursery school are followed through the seasons of the year and shows what children are like while they are learning and growing. It shows how teachers offer help by setting limits as well as by giving support and encouragement. Variety and suitability of play equipment for natural and constructive activity are indicated in the playroom and playground areas.

results.title: Learning is searching
results.creator_credit: L. Joseph Stone and Vassar College, Dept. of Child study
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Vassar studies: studies of normal personality development”.
A third grade in the New Lincoln School studies tools and their origins. The process of search is stressed. Shows the relation of these studies to the group’s other school activities. Presents the enthusiasm as well as the limitations of the children.

results.title: The Present from Gondwanaland
results.creator_credit: Mike Weatherley and British Broadcasting Corporation
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Up a gum tree”.
Two hundred million years ago the giant continent Gondwanaland split and Australia drifted away. Its plants and animals evolved in isolation from the rest of the world. How does a tree used as a prison fit into the story and what are the secrets of the gum tree’s success? Narrated by David Bellamy.

results.title: The Landscape architects; Fire down below
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Up a gum tree”.
The Landscape architects David Bellamy looks at how Aborigines learned to tame the countryside without becoming farmers, and at what sort of diet they enjoyed. “Fire Down Below” David Bellamy looks at the secrets of survival of the Australian flora against the frequent fires which seek to destroy.
